IMPORTANT NOTICE
All persons (aliens and American citizens)
must stop and report for customs inspection
before entering the United States. There is a
penalty for failure to report, It is advisable
that persons departing from the United States
check with custom officials regarding re-entry.
Total - 3,693 mi. in United States.
HIGHWAY MAP UNITED STATES
The Capitol of Pennsylvania as we pass through Harrisburg heading north for the Susquehanna River and Williamsport.

FIRST DAY — Saturday, August 2, 1958. Lancaster, Pa.
to Harrisburg, to Williamsport; enter New York state
to Niagara Falls; along Queen Elizabeth Way, Ontario
with cut-off to Beamsville (near Hamilton) for night.

blocks.text: North of North Bay we rise to a plateau and begin our long ride through the Great North Woods. We have been warned at a gas station we will see so many trees we will get tired looking at them. From North Bay to Fort William it is 709 miles.
A brief stop at a provincial park which features swimming and boating.

The Imperial arouses an unusual amount of interest in Canada. Almost everywhere we stop, people gather around to inspect the car. On one occasion, soon after entering Canada, Gordon pulled to the side of the road thinking there must be a mechanical defect since so many people in passing turned to stare.

blocks.text: A huge pile of wood to feed a chemical plant. Such industry is rare this far north.
Distances are vast, and this signboard tells us the long trip that lies ahead.
Velvet '98

Canada is building its first hard surfaced highway around Lake Superior as a link in the Trans-Canada highway from east to west...so, since there is only one road and no possible detours, we plow through two hundred miles of construction cut straight through the North Woods. West of the town of Hearst there is no gas available for one hundred miles (fortunately we are warned). Many immigrants have settled in this uncompromising north country. They are experiencing poor, lean, pioneer living on out over forest lands. Much of the region is still virgin forests.

blocks.text: Upper Red Lake

This has been a long day, darkness is fast coming on, and there is no sign of a place to spend the night...just forests on all sides. We envision a one automobile with a U.S. license plate... quite obviously this is not yet tourist country.

Finally, this "Snack Bar" where we can secure food, and fifty miles beyond a rustic cabin, without facilities, which the children enjoy as much as any night of the entire trip. From a nearby commissary we obtain food for breakfast in the cabin.

blocks.text: Having passed through the twin cities of Port Arthur and Fort William. We head in a north-western direction back into the wilderness. Mt. McKay overlooks Lake Superior.
Nancy stands beside a large sign which tells about the first Trans-Canada route.
This section of western Ontario contains literally thousands of lakes, many of them as yet unnamed. (See map preceding page.)
Gordon is using a map to ascertain distances only. There is only one road...we can't get lost. Farms and villages rare..

blocks.text: An old codger who puts gas into the Imperial remarks of the car: "I've pumped a lot of gas in my time, but I've never put gas in one of these things before."

An early stop for the night at Dryden, Ontario, a paper mill town. This motel is typical of most of the new motels, still far spaced, which are being erected to meet the increasing tourist trade. The owner's quarters are in the center. The cost for the night for our family is $12. These new motels all have modern conveniences.
WELCOME TO MANITOBA WHITESHELL FOREST RESERVE
Finally, the Manitoba line, after having travelled 1,378 miles in Ontario alone.

blocks.text: Roadside food stands look very much like those in the U. S. We are out of the woods and lakes region, in an area of cities and large wheat farms.
SIXTH DAY - Thursday, August 7, 1958. Virden, Manitoba, into Saskatchewan, to Regina, to Saskatoon, to North Battleford, Saskatchewan for night. 7:10 A.M. to 6:30 P.M. 447 miles – total 2,481 miles.
The highway and the rail road parallel each other for hundreds of miles across the Great Plains.
Early morning, we reach Saskatchewan, "The Wheat Province". Cindy and Gordon emphasize the long name, but actually there are as many letters in Pennsylvania.

blocks.text: From the line, 150 miles to Regina, modern capital city of Saskatchewan with a population of about 100,000. This is the post office where we get mail from home.
Small town of Lumsdened, 25 miles northwest of Regina. Lunch here. Food prices compare favorably with those in the U. S. Rarely are we served water unless we ask for it.
Harry's Cafe at Bladworth, Harry being the Chinese proprietor. Cindy and Louise make friends with his two boys. We are surprised by the large number of immigrants.

Most of the Plains' towns look alike: the railroad, the highway, the grain elevators, with the main part of town off to the side. Towns are seen from great distances because of the flatness and lack of trees.
This scene is unusual only because of the break in the monotonous flatness of the land. This appears to be a dried up river bed.

blocks.text: Prince Albert

This is a great, flat land of wheat fields with farm houses far apart. Towns are few and lacking in appeal. We are constantly impressed by the large number of immigrants who have chosen Canada for a new start in life.

blocks.text: SEVENTH DAY — Friday, August 8, 1958. North Battleford into Province of Alberta; to Elk Island National Park; to Edmonton; to Edson for night. 9:00 A. M. to 8:10 P. M. 377 miles - total 2,858 miles.

LLOYDMINSTER
The first settlers were the Bay Colonists. In 1806 they arrived by wagon from British India, and in 1824 moved to their present location on the North Saskatchewan River near Lloydminster.
In 1935 a new townsite was laid out with streets named after members of the original colony: E.L. Leland, H.E.
The town of Lloydminster, Alberta is right on the provincial line. It is interesting to note the town was founded by immigrants from England as recently as 1903.
After two hours' delay for muffler repairs, necessitated by plowing through roads under construction, we drive ninety miles to gain the Alberta line, our fourth province.

New Holland
"First in Crossland Farm Machinery."
Kathy, Kitty and Louise show they got their money's worth...T-bone steak for $1.
Here is a real surprise! This farm machinery dealer in Minburn, Alberta, handles products from New Holland Machine Co., Lancaster Co., Pa. Freight rates must be terrific.

The first settlers were the Bay Colonists. In 1806 they arrived by wagon from British India, and in 1824 moved to their present location on the North Saskatchewan River near Lloydminster.
In 1935 a new townsite was laid out with streets named after members of the original colony: E.L. Leland, H.E.
The town of Lloydminster, Alberta is right on the provincial line. It is interesting to note the town was founded by immigrants from England as recently as 1903.
After two hours' delay for muffler repairs, necessitated by plowing through roads under construction, we drive ninety miles to gain the Alberta line, our fourth province.

New Holland
"First in Crossland Farm Machinery."
Kathy, Kitty and Louise show they got their money's worth...T-bone steak for $1.
Here is a real surprise! This farm machinery dealer in Minburn, Alberta, handles products from New Holland Machine Co., Lancaster Co., Pa. Freight rates must be terrific.

blocks.text: Just west of Edmonton, capital city of Alberta, is the home of radio station CFRN, an unusual building which uses as its motif the totem pole.

At Edmonton we see the turn off to the Alaska Highway, with a sign indicating Alaska is 2000 miles to the northwest. The girls are all for going to Alaska, but Gordon adamantly (and wisely) insists upon heading straight for the Canadian Rockies.

blocks.text: . Here a meal in a log cabin cafe.
Louise holds what Gordon hopes is enough Canadian money to get us back to the United States. The unfavorable exchange is about 5% ($105 of our money for $100 of theirs).
Comfortable accommodations ($10) at Edson, Alberta, a tourist jump-off town for the Rockies, about 65 miles away.

EIGHTH DAY — Saturday, August 9, 1958. Edson, Alberta to Rocky Mountains at Jasper National Park; Jasper Park Lodge; Malignant Canyon; town of Jasper; Mt. Edith Cavell; south through Mountains to Sunwapta Falls in Jasper National Park.
Breakfast at Edson. Every one is in high spirits. The call of the mountains is in the air. The day is bright and clear.

blocks.text: First visit is to Maligne Canyon, reached by nine miles of steep, twisting mountain road with superb vistas of the surrounding peaks. The canyon itself is extremely narrow, several hundred feet deep, often dangerous in places. We follow the canyon for about a mile.

blocks.text: Kathy waves mail from home.

The Banff-Jasper Highway ranks among the great high-roads of the world. For its entire length of 185 mi. it commands some of the most breathtaking and majestic scenery in the Canadian Rockies. A panorama of unbroken mountain ranges extends along both sides of the road. At places the road reaches a height of 7000 feet above sea level. Many of the mountains rise to more than 10,000 feet and are perpetually snow-capped.
Jasper, our most western point, north of Washington.
Totem pole in the center of Jasper town.

Alongside the main Banff–Jasper highway the Athabasca River drops with a great roar into a canyon which is crossed by the highway.

blocks.text: The chant is: "Hurry up and take the picture....We're hungry."

We play it safe and stop at this rustic cabin ($8.25) in the early evening, after having covered only 198 miles this day ...but there has been a lot to see...and accommodations for the night are not plentifulful.

blocks.text: Although snowmobiles (look closely) are availableable to take you up the slope of the glacier, we decide to save our money for the chairlift at Banff.

( Opposite page ) The great glacial tongue of the Athabasca Glacier, protruding between Snow Dome and Mt. Athabasca, is part of the Columbia Icefield which covers an area of more than 100 square miles and reaches a depth of 1800 feet. It is the largest glacial mass outside the Arctic region.
Summit of Sunwapta Pass at 6,675 feet is the boundary between Jasper and Banff National Parks.
The scenery in Banff National Park rivals that of Jasper.

Set up for the tourist trade.
Valley road wi th sawed off peaks.
The road, a stream, and mountains with perpetual snow.

Steep side of the mountain on which we spy bighorn sheep.

blocks.text: A landmark visible from great distances is Mount Eisenhower. The name of the mountain was changed from Castle Mountain to honor General Dwight D. Eisenhower after the United States entry into the Second World War. Here we begin a climb over the mountains to the west heading for British Columbia.

blocks.text: Crownest Mountain (9,138') stands all by itself. We are back in the Province of Alberta.

ELEVENTH DAY - Tuesday, August 12, 1958. Blairmore, Alberta, to Waterton Lakes National Park; re-enter United States at Glacier National Park; Going-to-the Sun Highway; to Kalispell, Montana. 7:30 A. M. to 6:30 P. M. 229 miles - total 3,769 miles.

FRANK SLIDE APRIL 25 - 1908
Frank Slide was born in Germany on April 25, 1863. He emigrated to Canada with his parents when he was a young child and settled near St. Albert (now Edmonton). In the late nineteenth century, Frank became one of Alberta's most famous photographers.
He is best known for his haunting images of the Canadian prairies during their early years as an agricultural frontier in the 1890s - '20s. His work was widely published and he exhibited internationally. He died on April 25, 1943 at age eighty.
Lundbreck Falls of the Old Man River.
Flags of Canada and the United States at the entrance to Waterton-Glacier Int. Peace Park.
Farmlands with the Rockies in the background as we head due south from Pincher Creek.

blocks.text: Waterton Lakes National Park, a part of the Waterton-Glacier International Peace Park, covers 204 square miles along the eastern slope of the Rocky Mountains. The mountains arise almost abruptly from the plains. Here we shop for more than an hour, Kitty buying a plaid suit of imported material and Kathy secures a sweater. The other three girls abstain and request their share in cash. (Gordon finds, as usual, he can't win.)
Across the International Boundary at 12:30 noon, after 9½ days and 3,282 miles in Canada. A few questions asked, and we are back in the good old U. S. A.
Mountains as we approach the entrance to Glacier National Park.

blocks.text: Glacier National Park, lying athwart the Rocky Mountains of northwestern Montana, was created by act of Congress in 1910. It has an area of 1,600 square miles. There are more than 50 glaciers and 200 lakes. The Going-to-the-Sun Highway, a 50 miles long link between the east and west sides of the park, is one of the most spectacular mountain roads in America.
Little Chief Mountain and St. Mary Lake as the Going-to-the-Sun Highway begins its climb over the Rockies.

blocks.text: (Below) Surrounded by rocky pin-naclcs, graceful Tower Fall drops 132 feet to the basin below. Note people on rocks for comparison.

Yellowstone National Park, created in 1872, was the world's first national park. It was also the largest National Park in the United States, embracing 3,472 square miles in the northwest corner of Wyoming, and extending into Idaho and Montana. No other National Park has such a variety of natural phenomena.

blocks.text: (Refer to first trip to Yellowstone National Park in the summer of 1953.)

Large as Yellowstone is,
we found it crowded in places.
We cross Mount Washburn in a line of 15
cars at a speed of twenty
miles an hour. At meal times, the few cafeterias can not handle the crowds.
In the far distance can be seen the Lower Falls of Yellowstone River, twice as high as Niagara.
From Inspiration Point the visitor gazes straight down d1,200 feet to the floor of the Grand Canyon of the Yellowstone River.

blocks.text: OLD FAITHFUL GEYSER

Best known of all Yellowstone's attractions is Old Faithful Geyser,
which erupts on average of every 65 minutes. Column of water rises to height of 120–140 feet, with discharge of 10,000-15,000 gallons.

blocks.text: FOURTEENTH DAY - Friday, August 15, 1958. Jackson, Wyo. south through semi-desert section of Wyoming to Rock Springs; east through barren area to Rawlins and Laramie; enter Colorado to Ft. Collins. 7:55 A. M. to 6:20 P. M. 471 miles - total 4,871 miles.
Still in the mountains and wooded area, a sign points back to Jackson Hole; but we soon descend to monotonous desert country, with scattered sage the only vegetation.

Between Jackson and Rock Springs we traverse wide, open range country, with snow on the far distant mountains. There are few signs of habitation. We are lucky to see one automobile in every five miles. We cover the 177 miles in less than three hours.

South from Laramie we enter Colorado...the land becomes more rugged. Colorado has highest average altitude of any state, 6,800 feet, with Continental Divide running from north to south across the state.

blocks.text: FIFTEENTH DAY — Saturday, August 16, 1958. Ft. Collins, Colo. to Loveland; thru Rocky Mountain National Park; to Idaho Springs; to Idaho Springs; southwest to Dillon, Colo.; A. M. to 5:50 P. M. 230 miles – total 5,074 miles.
The front wheels of the car must be aligned, so we get away to a late start from Ft. Collins. We go away too early for a later start at Ft.
(See: first trip to the Rocky Mountain National Park in 1949, with Al & Pauline Spinner.)
Here the Trail Ridge Road is above timberline, literally riding the top of the Rockies. Many cars have been stalled by overheated engines. The Imperial takes the climb beautifully.

blocks.text: One of last things one would expect to find in this rough, mining country is the Hotel De Paris, with its rococo elegance, once the most famous hotel west of Mississippi River. Located in Georgetown, center of $90 million gold, silver, copper, lead and zinc region in times past.

(Right and below) Across the mountains via Loveland Pass at 11,988 feet, one of the highest main highway passes in the state. We have crossed and recrossed the Divide so many times we have lost track of the number. Note the complete lack of guard- rails (needless expense). The car is not running well, probably due to the high altitude.

blocks.text: DILLON DRUG DEPARTMENT STORE
SIXTEENTH DAY - Sunday, August 17, 1958. Dillon, Colo. to Leadville, to Salida, to Royal Gorge, to Canon City, to Colorado Springs. 9:45 A. M. to 5:35 P. M.
Ten hours sleep for everybody. Then car gets balky, due to altitude, and refuses to start for more than an hour.
Leadville, center of world's greatest mining district, retains charm of fabulous past. Many of original buildings survive. Town is two miles above sea level.

blocks.text: Mt. Elbert at 14,430 feet is highest point in Colo; not far from Leadville; other peaks have seemed higher, for Mt. Elbert rises from a high plateau.
One of the far separated ranches in the valleys of the Rockies.
The highway and the Arkansas River follow a deep canyon near Texas Creek.

At the town of Salida we put through a long dis-
tance phone call to Uncle Jim Landreth and Uncle
Tom Evans. From here, too our route is constantly eastward.
This buck deer with beautiful spread of antlers is attracted to Nancy by the salt on cashews she is offering.

blocks.text: Highest suspension bridge in the world is 1,053 feet over the Royal Gorge of the Arkansas River. Railroad tracks through the gorge are those of Denver & Rio Grande Western Railroad.

Gordon is a little annoyed: after following signs for several miles to the Royal Gorge, we find our-selves in a traffic box which leaves us no alternative but to pay $5 to cross the bridge, which leads only to a parking area on the other side.

blocks.text: SEVENTEENTH DAY - Monday, August 18, 1958. Colorado Springs, Colo. east into Kansas as far as Riley. 9:00 A. M. to 7:10 P. M. 465 miles - total 5,379 miles.
The best of the trip is behind us. Home lies 1,700 miles almost due east...across the Great Plains.

Just outside Colorado Springs the land has already turned flat, although the altitude is still over 5,000 feet. This altitude gradually and imperceptibly drops the further east we proceed. Every visitor is struck by the apparent suddenness with which the mountains end and the plains begin.
In central Kansas this sign tells us we are near the Geodetic Center of North America. Read the sign to discover what this means.
These Government storage bins for excess wheat are a common sight throughout the mid-west.

blocks.text: Blue Rapids Riley Manhattan Kansas City
Evansville
EIGHTEENTH DAY — Tuesday, August 19, 1958. Riley, Kansas to Kansas City; across Missouri; by-pass St. Louis; into Illinois (to near) Vandalia. 6:30 P.M. M. to 488 miles – total 5,227 miles.
Kitty examines a type of corn unknown to us ...seen frequently in the fields.
Near Manhattan, Kansas, a college town, our road crosses the old Oregon Trail. We bypass Topeka but see capitol dome in distance.
In Illinois after crossing Mississippi River. William Stratton, now Governor, is man who welcomed Gordon to Springfield when Gordon was National President of A. B. C.
Buying fruit at a roadside stand in Missouri. Travel 255 miles in Missouri from Kansas City to St. Louis. Now on R#40 all the way to Washington, Pa.

NINETEENTH DAY - Wednesday, August 20, 1958. Vandalia, Ill. to Indianapolis, Ind.; to Columbus, Ohio; to Wheeling, W. Va; to Washington, Pa; onto Pennsylvania Turnpike...and home. 7:45 A. M. to 3:10 A. M.
Breakfast at this cafe near Vandalia, Illinois, short distance from motel for night ($8.50).
Time out for milk shake and chocolate sundaes.
End - Trip to Rocky Mountains of Canada and the United States.

Breakfast at this cafe near Vandalia, Illinois, short distance from motel for night ($8.50).
Time out for milk shake and chocolate sundaes.
End - Trip to Rocky Mountains of Canada and the United States.
